instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Thermal Sensor Issue
threads.message:
Hello,

The board originally came in for no power. It had a short in the PCB on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> near J6430 caused by liquid damage. That was cleaned and the short in the PCB was cleared, now the Macbook turns on and boots but the fans run at full speed and runs slow. I ran HWmonitor and the only thing that stands out is the Airport temp sensor but that seems to be normal. All the other temps read fine, nothing stands out. I've tried another keyboard assembly with a known good track and also tried the board without the LCD plugged it as well as tried it with a known working LCD. 

Although the areas looked good I also changed <CHIP>U5850</CHIP>, <CHIP>U5860</CHIP> and <CHIP>U5870</CHIP> but there wasn't any change. All the chips are being power, the resistors in their circuits tested good, and nothing stands out with the caps or traces as well.

Any suggestions or help would be appreciative. Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Thermal Sensor Issue
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Airport temp sensor is based on <CHIP>U5820</CHIP>.
Check the traces and <RESISTOR>R5820</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Thermal Sensor Issue
threads.message:
Thanks for the reply.

The issue was a trace between Pin 8 of <CHIP>U5850</CHIP> and Pin 6 of <CHIP>U5820</CHIP>. Ran a wire and it works great now. Thanks for your help.
